headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Joplin After the Tornado
summary: See aerial shots of Joplin, Mo., before and after Sunday evening's tornado.

headline: New Fuel Economy Labels
summary: The Obama administration unveiled Wednesday its revamp of fuel economy labels for new cars and trucks. See samples of the new design.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of May 24, 2011

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for May 25, 2011

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Fred Siegel on residents' continuing exodus from New York state.

headline: Obama to Visit Chrysler Plant
summary: President Barack Obama will visit an Ohio auto plant next week to make the case that the administration's bailout of General Motors and Chrysler Co. has fundamentally changed the companies.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: A protest in Nepal demanding a new constitution, children of China's migrant workers dance outside containers used as their classrooms, art from Hong Kong International Art Fair, and more.

headline: Georgian Police Disperse Protesters
summary: Georgian police used water cannons, tear gas and rubber bullets to dispel antigovernment demonstration in capital early Thursday.

headline: Hotel Leelaventure Plans to Raise Capital
summary: Hotel Leelaventure decided at its board meeting to raise $222 million, and plans to seek shareholder approval for it.

headline: Democrats Seek Limits on Speculative Trading
summary: Senate Democrats are going to press for limits on speculative trading in the energy markets Thursday during a meeting with the chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: Singapore Airlines to Establish Budget Carrier
summary: Singapore Airlines announced that it will establish a budget airline catering to cost-conscious travelers on longer-distance routes.

headline: Charter Jet Skids Off Runway
summary: A small business jet skidded off the runway while landing in Sedona, Ariz., but the five people aboard walked away from the accident uninjured, according to the plane's operator.

headline: In Rescue Effort, 7 Bodies Recovered
summary: At a Home Depot in a commercial strip in central Joplin, rescuers had pulled seven bodies from the front end of the store, including a father and his one and 3-year old sons.

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Thursday, May 26, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: FDA Sued Over Antibiotics in Animal Feed
summary: Several environment and health-advocacy groups are suing the FDA to ban the widespread use of two antibiotics in animal feed to treat livestock.

headline: Edwards's Lawyers in Plea Talks
summary: Justice Department prosecutors and lawyers for former Sen. John Edwards are in plea agreement talks that could avert felony charges over alleged campaign-finance violations.

headline: Cass Sunstein: 21st-Century Regulation—An Update on the President's Reforms
summary: Federal agencies are eliminating unnecessary rules to save businesses money.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: House Majority Leader Eric Cantor offers a story that captures the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Obama to Visit Chrysler Plant
summary: President Obama will visit an Ohio auto plant next week to make the case that the bailout of General Motors and Chrysler has fundamentally changed the two companies.

headline: Liu Drops Federal Bench Bid
summary: Law professor Goodwin Liu dropped his bid for the federal bench, with a letter asking Obama to withdraw his nomination to the Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco.

headline: Nicholas E. Calio: The Air Travel 'Sin' Tax
summary: The tax bite on a typical domestic ticket has nearly tripled to $61 from $22 in 1972.

headline: Feds Look at Avon Bribery Allegation
summary: Federal prosecutors are investigating several former Avon employees, raising the prospect of criminal charges in an ongoing probe into allegations the company bribed foreign officials.

headline: Keiko Fujimori Struggles With Her Father's Legacy
summary: As Peru nears a June 5 runoff election for president, Keiko Fujimori's opponents are focusing on events from her father's 1990-to-2000 term, and trying to tar her by association.

headline: Highway Measure May Be Scaled Back
summary: A six-year $556 billion highway and transit construction program proposed by President Barack Obama is the latest casualty of Washington's spending stalemate.

headline: President Obama in London
summary: U.S. President Barack Obama arrived in the U.K. for his second stop on a four-country, six-day European tour. Look at highlights from his trip.

headline: Grilling with Gusto
summary: Chef Anita Lo prepares fish, meats and sweets for a back yard cookout.

headline: Greece Worries Damp Euro
summary: Greek debt concerns outweighed encouraging signs about global growth, sending the euro briefly down to a record low against the safe-haven Swiss franc.

headline: An IRS Power Could Be Expanded
summary: IRS agents could see their powers expanded if lawmakers decide to widen their math-error authority, which helps IRS workers quickly fix a variety of errors that civilians make on their tax returns, often to taxpayers' benefit.

headline: Dow Halts 3-Day Skid
summary: Investors rode a boost in commodities prices to snap up shares of energy, materials and industrial companies.

headline: Bid to Use Gold as Collateral Advances
summary: Investors are closer to being able to put up gold as collateral after an agreement among European regulators, the World Gold Council said.

headline: Insurers' Profit Margins Fall
summary: Powerful earthquakes in Japan and New Zealand caused U.S. property-casualty insurers to post their worst first-quarter profit margins in a decade.

headline: Killings of Sea Lions Suspended
summary: Wildlife advocates reached an agreement with the states of Oregon and Washington and a federal agency to temporarily halt killings of California sea lions at the Columbia River's Bonneville Dam this year.

headline: Tim Hortons CEO Leaves
summary: Tim Hortons  said its CEO is no longer with the coffee-shop chain and that it is searching for a replacement.

headline: Amazon's Cheaper Kindle Displays Ads
summary: Amazon.com launched another version of its popular Kindle electronic reader that is cheaper but that comes with on-screen ads.

headline: Joplin Home Depot 'Severely Damaged' by Tornado
summary: A Home Depot Inc. store in Joplin, Mo., is closed Monday after being "severely damaged" by the tornado that struck the Midwestern city, claiming scores of lives and shuttering or destroying dozens of other businesses.

headline: S&P Warns of Profit Squeeze for China's Banks
summary: Standard & Poor's warned that government anti-inflation efforts are likely to squeeze profits at China's banks, highlighting growing concern about the impact of tighter monetary policy on lenders that have poured out credit in recent years to help drive growth in the world's No. 2 economy.

headline: Banks Lead Europe Higher; Shanghai Falls
summary: European stocks closed slightly higher after credit-ratings firm Fitch Ratings said it doesn't foresee any rating action on German banks as a result of their exposure to Greece. Asian markets ended mostly lower.

headline: Ex-Galleon Trader Testifies on Tips
summary: A former Galleon trader testified that he was told trader Zvi Goffer was the source of several secret tips regarding potential mergers and other deals.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 25
summary: In today's pictures, cadets graduate from the U.S. Air Force Academy, a newborn listens to music in Slovakia, girls play in a sandstorm in Pakistan and more.

headline: Women Accuse French Official
summary: Two women jointly filed a criminal sexual-harassment complaint against French junior minister Georges Tron, a sign of heightened sensitivity to inappropriate behavior as the Dominique Strauss-Kahn situation unfolds.

headline: Nymex Crude Rebounds
summary: Crude-oil futures settled above $101 a barrel for the first time in two weeks, spurred by U.S. oil-inventory data showing stronger demand from refiners.

headline: Citi's Havens Rebuilds Investment Bank
summary: Citigroup President John Havens is working to overcome the injuries, many self-inflicted, its investment bank suffered in the financial meltdown.

headline: Bearish Bets Decrease at NYSE
summary: Short selling at the New York Stock Exchange fell in the first half of May, according to the latest twice-monthly figures for the exchange.

headline: Creating Entrepreneurial Buzz in Silicon Valley
summary: Stanford's SSE Labs is emerging as a clubhouse of choice for some talented young entrepreneurs.

headline: Utah Warns BofA on Foreclosures
summary: The Utah attorney general sent Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan a letter last week warning him one the bank's units was conducting illegal foreclosures in Utah.

headline: Hormel Gives Cautious View
summary: Hormel expects margins for its pork and turkey processing businesses will fall from lofty levels as costs for hogs and feed for turkeys increase.

headline: Watson Buys Greek Drug Maker
summary: Watson Pharmaceuticals acquired privately held Greek generic-drug developer Specifar in a deal valued at upward of $560 million.

headline: Greek PM Renews Call for Consensus
summary: Prime Minister George Papandreou renewed his call for a national consensus to address the country's financial crisis, one day after failing to find common ground with opposition lawmakers over the government's latest austerity measures.

headline: LinkedIn Stock Is Costly to Short
summary: LinkedIn's stock is one of the U.S. market's most talked-about "shorts" and one of the most costly.

headline: U.S. Raises Dairy-Price Forecast
summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture raised its forecast for retail dairy prices on higher demand and transportation costs but left its overall food-inflation projection for the year unchanged.

headline: No Agreement on Web Governance at Summit
summary: The Internet could be regulated, but not too much, not too soon and preferably not by a government. That is the broad take-away from two days of debate about the role of the Internet in society and the economy at the e-G8 summit in Paris.

headline: South Africa Considers IMF Nomination
summary: South Africa is mulling whether to nominate its own candidate for the position of managing director of the IMF or to support someone from another developing country, a Treasury spokesman said.

headline: Russia, Shell Discuss Arctic Shelf Projects
summary: Royal Dutch Shell CEO Peter Voser met Russia's top energy official to discuss joint projects on Russia's Arctic shelf, the Black Sea and Sakhalin-3, but he said the company won't seek to swap shares with state oil giant Rosneft.

headline: What's Old is New
summary: Procter & Gamble Co., General Mills Inc., Hostess Brands Inc. and PepsiCo Inc. are pulling old package designs out of their archives for brands like Tide, Cheerios and Doritos and bringing them back to store shelves. See some examples of new and old packaging.

headline: Australians Among World's Happiest
summary: No worries, mate: Australia may be the world's happiest industrialized nation by one reckoning, even as it grapples with rising inflation, pricey housing and worries that it is developing a two-track economy.

headline: Jerry Brown's New Reason to Extend Tax Hikes
summary: Most governors would love a windfall of revenue, but an unexpected inflow in California is complicating the Democrat's campaign to extend tax hikes.

headline: Hochul Win Is GOP Wake-Up Call
summary: Democrat Kathy Hochul claimed victory last night in New York's pivotal House special election.

headline: Flights Seen Resuming as Ash Clears
summary: Meteorologists said they expect the volcanic-ash clouds that have grounded hundreds of European flights to disappear during the day, allowing airlines to resume normal services.

headline: Genworth Road to Recovery Requires Investors' Patience
summary: Genworth Financial has outlined a road map and a schedule for impatient investors for how the insurer's recovery will happen. But its CEO has warned that it will take some time.

headline: European Stocks Eke Out Gains
summary: European stocks clambered out of the red after credit-ratings firm Fitch Ratings said it doesn't foresee any rating action on German banks as a result of their exposure to Greece.

headline: Quake May Have Damaged Plant
summary: The operator of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant acknowledged that at least some damage to the plant may have been caused by the earthquake that struck March 11, not solely by the tsunami that followed.

headline: Taiwan Risks Trade Isolation, Group Warns
summary: A warning from a government trade council in Taiwan highlights concerns that the island has become increasingly isolated by the burgeoning network of free trade agreements connecting Asia and the rest of the world.

headline: Toyota Distributor Offers Sales Incentives
summary: A major U.S. distributor for Toyota in the Southeast has sweetened sales incentives to spur lagging auto sales.

headline: Softbank to Invest in Solar Project
summary: Softbank plans to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to help build solar-power plants in Japan, seeking to move beyond its core telecom businesses.

headline: Citic Securities Plans Sale of Fund-Manager Stake
summary: Citic Securities plans to sell a 51% stake in its asset-management company for at least $1.16 billion as it prepares for a Hong Kong listing.

headline: Oprah and Guests
summary: Oprah Winfrey's iconic TV talk show will end in 2011 after 25 seasons on the air, her production company said.

headline: FSA Fines Lloyds Unit for Complaint Mishandling
summary: Bank of Scotland, Lloyds Banking Group's main banking unit in Scotland, said it will compensate customers for not properly handling complaints over the bank's sale of several retail-investment products.

headline: Portugal Spending Cuts Questioned
summary: Controversy on how Portugal is meeting its budget deficit targets under a €78 billion bailout deal is brewing after a parliamentary agency said that more than €200 million in first-quarter state spending cuts actually came from unpaid bills.

headline: Commodities IPOs Face Uncertain Market
summary: Resourcehouse, the Australian miner raising up to $3.6 billion in its fourth attempt at an IPO in Hong Kong, is delaying its listing date in the city by a day, while shares in commodities giant Glencore International closed 2.5% lower on their Hong Kong debut.

headline: EU Sets Nuclear Stress-Test Criteria
summary: The European Union has agreed to test its nuclear plants for natural disasters such as earthquakes and tsunamis, as well as for man-made catastrophes, while leaving the sensitive issue of terrorist attack-prevention for later.

headline: China Concerns Dog Asia Stocks
summary: Most Asian markets ended lower, with Chinese shares dragged down on worries about slowing economic growth and rising inflationary pressure; the Shanghai Composite fell for the fifth straight day, losing 0.9%.

headline: Upper West Side Escape
summary: The owners once used this renovated duplex on West 81st Street for weekend excursions from the suburbs, but now family life comes first.

headline: MAN Probes Fuel-Efficiency Claims
summary: MAN said it has informed public prosecutors that it is investigating whether its four-stroke marine diesel engines may have been tampered with to make them appear more fuel-efficient.

headline: ECB Won't Try to Weaken Euro
summary: The European Central Bank won't attempt to weaken the euro to boost exports, ECB executive board member Jürgen Stark said, highlighting that the central bank instead has started to tighten policy in a bid to combat inflation.

headline: Cairn India Profit Soars
summary: Cairn India topped analyst estimates with a 10-fold jump in quarterly profit, boosted by higher crude oil prices and a ramp-up in production at India's biggest onshore field in the northwestern state of Rajasthan.

headline: Prepare for an Attack of the China Bears
summary: High levels of investment and low domestic consumption are a reminder of all the things wrong with China's economy. But investors should remember that in developing economies it's investment, not consumption, that drives growth.

headline: Bank of Montreal Profit Tops Expectations
summary: Bank of Montreal kicked off the second-quarter reporting season for Canada's big banks with a 7% rise in earnings.

headline: Google, Citigroup to Invest in California Wind Farm
summary: Google and Citigroup said they will each invest $55 million in an inland California wind farm they said will be the country's largest by the end of the year.

headline: Japanese Yields Lean Lower
summary: Japanese government bond yields were flat to lower, and analysts said it remains difficult to see a reason for yields to rise sharply.

headline: Squeezed Britons Hold Back Recovery
summary: A slump in consumer spending, a drop in bank lending to businesses, and the OECD's lowering of its growth forecast combined to reinforce doubts about whether Britain's economic recovery can withstand the government's ambitious spending cuts.

headline: DP World Plans June U.K. Listing
summary: Dubai-based ports operator DP World said it expects to list shares on the London Stock Exchange on June 1, a move the government-controlled company is banking on to lift its international profile and boost liquidity.

headline: Bank of India Board OKs Fund-Raising
summary: Bank of India's board approved a plan to raise fresh capital by selling up to 180 million shares, in line with similar share sale plans of other local banks as they seek to beef up their capital base to feed rising loan demand.

headline: CIMB Net Profit Rises 9.4%
summary: Malaysian lender CIMB Group Holdings' net profit rose on lower loan loss provisions even as it reported lower net interest and non-interest income. It also dropped plans to for a dual listing in Thailand.

headline: Zale's Loss Narrows as Sales Rise
summary: Zale's fiscal-third-quarter loss narrowed as the jewelry retailer registered double-digit gains in revenue and same-store sales.

headline: Religare Capital Names New Managing Director
summary: Religare Capital Markets, the investment banking arm of Religare Enterprises, on Wednesday said it has appointed Gautam Trivedi as managing director and head of institutional equities for India.

headline: Sycamore Networks' Loss Widens
summary: Sycamore Networks' fiscal-third-quarter loss widened as revenue and interest income declined.

headline: Bosch Electrical to Set up New Auto-Parts Unit
summary: Bosch's joint venture with Igarashi Motors India will invest $8.16 million to set up a factory to make auto components in the southern city of Chennai.

headline: Ash Cloud Begins to Clear Out
summary: Ash clouds caused by the eruption of Iceland's Grimsvötn volcano cleared the U.K., Ireland and Scandinavia on Wednesday, but areas of ash concentration over parts of northern Germany caused disruption.

headline: Infosys Leads India Shares Lower
summary: Indian shares fell Wednesday ahead of the expiry of May derivatives, with Infosys Technologies leading software stocks lower after the technology bellwether was subpoenaed by a U.S. federal court in connection with alleged visa law violations.

headline: OECD Sees Japan Recovering in Third Quarter
summary: Japan's economy will remain mired in recession through the second quarter but will then post a strong recovery in the second half as supply chains are re-established and recovery spending helps spur growth, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.

headline: The India-Africa Forum Summit
summary: Speaking at the second edition of the summit, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh pledged India will loan $5 billion to African countries. Some snapshots.

headline: iPhone 4 to Launch in India May 27
summary: Bharti Airtel and Aircel said they will start selling Apple Inc.'s iPhone 4 smartphones in India from May 27.

headline: Vietnam Trade Deficit Widens
summary: Vietnam's persistent trade deficit widened to its largest point in 17 months in May, putting further pressure on authorities to address imbalances in the economy.

headline: German Consumer Mood Declines
summary: German consumer confidence is set to fall further in June as high energy prices and Greece's debt crisis weigh on consumer mood, market research group GfK said.

headline: DLF to Sell Assets to Raise Money
summary: DLF, the property developer, has more than doubled its fund-raising target to $2.2 billion. The company will sell some non-core assets over the next two to three years to generate cash for its core property development business and cut debt.

headline: BOJ Open to Further Stimulus Measures
summary: Bank of Japan Gov. Masaaki Shirakawa indicated Wednesday that he is open to additional steps to stimulate economic growth in the aftermath of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, while saying that he sees some positive economic signs already emerging.

headline: Chennai in Final
summary: Chennai Super Kings sealed a place in the IPL4 final after beating Royal Challengers Bangalore by six wickets in a nail-biting match.

headline: OECD Predicts Moderate Euro-Zone Growth
summary: The euro-zone economy should continue its moderate recovery over the next two years, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in its annual forecast.

headline: Firstsource Expects Better Margins This Year
summary: Firstsource Solutions expects its operating margins to improve in the current fiscal year as the volume of outsourcing work increases, despite prices remaining constant, a senior executive said.

headline: Foray into Real Estate
summary: , chairman of financial services firm ASK Investment Holdings, has floated a real estate company, Pashmina Developers, with an undisclosed investment from his personal funds.

headline: Few Deals Make the Cut: Morgan Stanley Infra
summary: , managing director at Morgan Stanley Infrastructure Partners, said in an interview that doing diligence on infrastructure deals in India is one of the most challenging aspects of investing in the sector.

headline: Subbarao: States Can Help Inflation Management
summary: India's central bank chief Duvvuri Subbarao said that states are important stakeholders in inflation management as they can help address supply-side constraints.

headline: Indian Hotels to Raise Stake in Piem Hotels
summary: Indian Hotels will invest up to 510 million rupees to raise its stake in unlisted Piem Hotels, an associate company of Indian Hotels, by end of this month.

headline: Conditions Favorable For Monsoon Onset
summary: Weather conditions for the onset of monsoon rains over India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands have improved after a delay and the rains are likely to reach in the next two to three days, an official with India's Meteorological Department said.

headline: Growth Worries to Plague Chinese Shares
summary: China's stock market risks continued weakness in the near term, and its performance for the rest of the year looks increasingly uncertain due to mounting concerns about slowing economic growth and persistently high inflation.

headline: Wal-Mart Loses Two Top Executives in China
summary: Wal-Mart Stores has lost two of its top executives in China, potentially complicating the retail giant's expansion in a key growth market.

headline: Li Ning Loses Executives
summary: Three executives of Chinese sports-apparel maker Li Ning have left the fast-growing company. Li Ning called it normal management turnover.

headline: Morgan Stanley Infra Forms New Venture
summary: Morgan Stanley Infrastructure Partners, a $4 billion global infrastructure fund, announced a $400 million joint venture with Spain-based Isolux Corsán on Tuesday that will invest in roads in India.

headline: Suven Seeks Foreign Partner, Mulls Options
summary: Suven Life Sciences is scouting for a foreign partner to take its molecule SUVN-502 into human trials. The company already has completed animal studies on the experimental drug to treat schizophrenia and Alzheimer's disease.

headline: Export Tumble Puts Japan in Deficit
summary: Japanese exports in April were down for a second consecutive month, tipping the trade balance into a deficit as damages from the earthquake continued to hobble production and shipments of industrial goods.

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, May 25, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Critics Fault NYU Growth Plan
summary: New York University heard from numerous critics and some supporters as it began an environmental impact review of a plan to expand the school's Greenwich Village campus.

headline: Where's the Rail Cost-Benefit Study?
summary: regarding Secretary of Transportation Ray LaHood Letter of May 24: Why  is his own Federal Railroad Administration unable to produce even one cost-benefit analysis to support its proposed expenditures on high-speed rail in California, or elsewhere

headline: The Rise of ESPN: Now in Book Form
summary: ESPN has become nearly everything. Maybe it could be a little more Like Mike (Tyson).

headline: Gates Urges Iraq to Let U.S. Troops Stay
summary: Defense Secretary Robert Gates urged Iraq to host U.S. troops beyond the end of the year to maintain stability and keep Iran at bay, echoing the growing concerns of U.S. military officials.

headline: Smallpox-Destruction Deadline Delayed
summary: Global health officials delayed setting a deadline for the destruction of the last known stocks of smallpox for at least three more years, a compromise that will enable scientists in the U.S. and Russia to continue researching medicines to counter a potential bioterror attack using smallpox.

headline: Dialing Up the Phone War
summary: Microsoft showed off an upgraded version of its Windows Phone software, as the company attempts to claw its way back into the smartphone business.

headline: Iraq the Model
summary: Bob Gates talks about the Arab world's foremost democracy.

headline: Wife, Mistress Battle Over President's Burial
summary: When he was president of Venezuela, Carlos Andrés Pérez kept the two families he fathered—one with his wife, the other with a mistress—in separate spheres. But when he died, decades of simmering resentment spewed forth.

headline: What Women Still Can't Have
summary: A reader responds to Anne Jolis's May 19 op-ed, "What Women Want."

headline: Socialites, Literary Lions Mark Library Centennial
summary: Monday's Centennial Rededication Gala for the New York Public Library, celebrating, quite obviously, 100 years of the noble institution, now called the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, felt a lot like a college graduation.

headline: Fighting Spurs Fears of War in Yemen
summary: Yemen edged closer to civil war as opposition fighters seized government buildings and Washington stepped up pressure on the embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to step aside.

headline: Commodities Go Their Separate Ways
summary: The recent fall in commodities prices has been far from uniform. After years of close correlation in commodity prices, investors need to become more discerning.

headline: Vermont Health Plan Advances
summary: Vermont is moving one step closer to a goal of its Democratic governor: a state-run health plan that would insure most of its 625,000 residents.

headline: The Case Against Roger Maris*
summary: Looking beyond his home-run record for the 1961 season, does Roger Maris truly deserve to be inducted into the Hall of Fame?

headline: Treasurys Rise After Strong Two-Year Sale
summary: A strong bid in the sale of a $35 billion two-year note, signaling persistent concerns about U.S. growth and the euro zone's sovereign-debt crisis, boosted safe-haven Treasurys.

headline: China's Growth Risks
summary: Rising inflation and an opaque financial system, among others.

headline: Cantor Aims to Change Game
summary: Howard Lutnick, CEO of investment-banking firm Cantor Fitzgerald, doesn't just want to join the commercial real-estate game. He wants to change how it is played.

headline: India Remains Cautious on Food Exports
summary: India will not allow any wheat or rice exports from government stocks, despite huge supplies from bumper crops as the country is gearing up to soon introduce a food security law that guarantees cheap foodgrains to 70% of the population, the country's food minister said in an interview.

headline: Toshiba Lays Out Agenda
summary: With its once-promising nuclear power business surrounded by difficulties, Toshiba rolled out an aggressive spending plan for the next three years in an attempt to find a viable long-term strategy.

headline: Leap Wireless Opposes T-Mobile Deal
summary: Leap Wireless became the latest wireless carrier to voice opposition to AT&T's $39 billion bid to purchase T-Mobile, citing anti-competitive issues.

headline: TV Shows Channel New York
summary: Eight new prime-time series are slated to shoot in New York, as the city recovers from the loss of long-time TV denizens.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Right to Work Isn't All Laffer Implies
summary: Laffer notes that populations have grown faster in the 22 states with such laws, concentrated in the South and Southwest.

headline: Cruising With the Stars
summary: From Dan Rather to Buzz Aldrin, celebrities are taking the free ride cruise lines are offering to entertain passengers and gain a competitive edge.

headline: Jenkins: Know Thy Bond Vigilante
summary: A fiscal resolution that raises taxes and kills growth might satisfy the bond market and no one else.

headline: Congress Applauds Israeli's Hard Line
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu laid out a hard-line position on the creation of a future Palestinian state to a joint session of Congress and received more than 25 standing ovations.

headline: More on Stanley Druckenmiller and the Risk of Default
summary: The Journal encourages the idea that the threat of a debt default might help force entitlement reform ("The Weekend Interview with Stanley Druckenmiller: What If the U.S. Treasury Defaults?," by James Freeman, May 14).

headline: NATO Steps Up Libya Campaign
summary: NATO warplanes bombarded Tripoli in what appeared to be the heaviest night of bombing in the air campaign, and the U.S. invited Libya's rebel leadership to open an office in Washington.

headline: Shelby Steele: Obama's Unspoken Re-Election Edge
summary: This presidency flatters America to a degree that no white Republican can hope to match.

headline: U.K. Welcomes Obama
summary: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were welcomed to Buckingham Palace by Queen Elizabeth II as they began their official state visit to Britain.

headline: Europe's Dispute on Debt Intensifies
summary: The dispute between Europe's central bankers and politicians over how to deal with Greece's worsening financial problems intensified, as one of the European Central Bank's top officials rejected calls by Germany and other euro-zone states for a restructuring of Greek debt—calling it a "horror scenario."

headline: Auto Makers Sweeten the Recipe for Small Cars
summary: Auto makers are reinventing small, fuel-efficient cars for American drivers, just in time for another bout of angst caused by gasoline prices of $4 a gallon and up in many cities and forecasts that oil prices will rebound from their recent dip.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of May 25, 2011

headline: Mortgage Securities on a Roll in 2011
summary: After returning from the dead in 2010, the commercial-mortgage-backed-securities sector is expanding further in 2011.
